Award.AwardTitle: The Structural Basis for Fracture Toughness and Elasticity of Metallic Glasses
Award.AbstractNarration: TECHNICAL: Bulk metallic glasses combine some of the outstanding mechanical properties of metals, including high strength and stiffness, with the processing flexibility of glasses. They do have a significant limitation, however, in that localization of plastic deformation into shear bands leads to fracture at small plastic strains, particularly in tension. Nevertheless, some metallic glasses are quite tough (with fracture energies similar to those of high strength crystalline alloys) while others are truly brittle. The origins of this difference are not well understood. An understanding of the fundamental physical mechanisms responsible would be an important contribution to the development of new alloys with improved toughness and damage tolerance. PI seeks to address this challenge through a research program that combines experimental and computational techniques to explore fundamental aspects of the competition between plastic deformation and fracture of metallic glasses. The recently observed correlation between elastic properties and fracture energy is a potentially useful link for understanding the relationship between structure and fracture. PI will examine the competition between brittle fracture and plastic flow in detail. A centerpiece of this effort will be detailed structural characterization of the plastic zone around a crack tip using high energy x-ray scattering performed in situ during loading. This technique allows measurement of elastic strain (and thus stresses) in the metallic glass with excellent (~10 um) spatial resolution in both the crystalline and amorphous phases. This will allow PI to explore the conditions under which shear bands are initiated near crack tips. As part of this effort, PI will explore the effects of three variables known to mediate the transition between brittle and tough behavior: temperature, structural relaxation, and alloy composition. The goal is to develop a detailed, realistic model of the mechanism by which a region of distributed plastic deformation develops around a crack tip. The second major aspect of this program will be to explore how the elastic properties and the shear modulus in particular, are influenced by anelastic atomic rearrangements. PI seeks to correlate observed changes in structure under load with measured changes in the elastic constants, under the influence of temperature, relaxation, and composition. PI will also connect this behavior to structure through detailed ex situ characterization, including resonant x-ray scattering and fluctuation electron microscopy. By understanding the ways in which atomic rearrangements (which may be connected to plastic deformation) influence the shear modulus PI can begin to understand the connection between elastic properties and fracture at a fundamental level. NON-TECHNICAL: The research program will advance the education and training of graduate students, undergraduate students, and local high school students by integrating them into a research team that includes the PI and the other members of his research group. The results of the basic scientific research will be disseminated via journal publications, conference and seminar presentations (by the undergraduate and graduate students as well as the principal investigator), and the web. High school students, including some from under-represented groups, will participate through a cooperative program with Project Ingenuity at Baltimore Polytechnic High School.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When a force is applied to a material, the material resists the force and is said to be under stress. Stresses in materials are important in all sorts of ways; in particular, a material can only withstand so much stress before it fails, either by bending (called "plastic deformation") or breaking ("fracture"). Naturally, stresses leading to failure are of great interest to engineers, and there is therefore also great interest in being able to measure stresses in materials.
For many years, a technique called x-ray diffraction has been used to measure stresses in materials in which the atoms are arranged in regularly ordered arrays (although the arrays usually have many defects). Such materials are said to be "crystalline" and include most metals and many ceramics. Briefly, the x-ray diffraction technique works by measuring the distance between atoms in the material; in a material under compression, for example, the atoms are squeezed closer together. Knowing the distances between atoms and how they change in response to a force (the so-called "elastic constants"), we can work out the stress in the material.
There has been a gap, however, in our ability to measure stresses with x-ray diffraction. Many materials are not crystalline; instead, the atoms are arranged in a more-or-less random way and are said to be "amorphous." Although diffraction has been used to measure stresses in these materials, there have been some strange observations that led many researchers to doubt whether the measurements were accurate, or whether there was something fundamentally difference about amorphous solids that would prevent us from measuring stress using diffraction.
In this project, we conducted tests of stress measurement under a variety of loading conditions (compression and tension, for example) and showed that diffraction can indeed be used to measure stress accurately. We also worked out some of the puzzling aspects of earlier measurements, using computer simulations of the atomic motions, and showed that they occur because the atoms move in a non-uniform way: In some regions the atoms move a lot in response to the applied force, while in others they move only a little.
All of this was secondary to our primary goal: To use diffraction to study the stresses around very sharp crack tips in metallic glasses, and understand how and why metallic glasses fracture. In particular, we were interested in why metallic glasses can be tough (resistant to fracture) at room temperure, but become brittle at low temperatures. Using our x-ray diffracton technique we mapped out the stresses around crack tips in glasses at various temperatures (see attached figure), and were able to show that the brittleness of glasses at low temperatures is a result of the fact that the cracks are very sharp. At higher temperatures the glass can flow slightly to make the tip of the crack more blunt. This distributes the stress more evenly through the material and makes it more resistant to fracture.
This work has significance not only for understanding of fracture in metallic glasses, but because x-ray scattering can be used with confidence to measure stresses in other amorphous materials, including other kinds of glasses but potentially polymers as well. As part of this work, two graduate students earned doctoral degrees in materials science and engineering and went on to employment (one in the private sector and one in a government lab). Two undergradates also participated in the research; one of them has gone on to graduate school, and the other will when she completes her undergraduate degree in spring 2013.
